text: My blade corrodes, but it never breaks—same as me.
His encrusted skin and warped physiology make Olg unnaturally hardy against fatigue and pain.
His weapons are corroded by brine, but they bite through steel like rot through wood.
Though Olg never prayed to Khorne, the Blood God seems to answer him all the same.
The winds of the northern coast whisper plunder, and Olg listens well.
Olg leaves heaps of rusted weapons and torn armor at sea’s edge—silent tribute to unseen powers.
Olg seeks forbidden knowledge from prisoners, often dragging secrets from them before their final breath.
The Skaelings believe his vomit is the bile of Khorne himself—proof of divine fury.
Olg Blóðsalt is the Brine Drinker: not yet a legend, but already feared like one.
He was blessed to survive, cursed to corrode — Olg’s fury steers him deeper into ruinous tides, Khorne's gaze looming over his every battle.
A Skaeling relic long thought lost, the mask fuses to its wearer and feeds them visions of drowned empires.
Melee attack: %+n for the Brutes of the Hound
Pitted and bloated with oxidized salt, this axe leaves a trail of hissing corrosion across the wounds it inflicts.
Local Recruitment duration: %+n turn for all Marauder Champion and Huscarl units
Marauder mobs are awarded even greater mobility when riding their crude chariots of bone and wood, lashed together with the guts and sinew of the vanquished.
Olg can unleash a torrent of burning salt vomit, blinding enemies and corroding metal with unnatural fury.

Olg Blóðsalt is a young Skaeling captain whose name already echoes across the northern fjords and salt-scarred coastlines. At just nineteen, he bears the mark of the gods—though whether as a blessing or a curse, none can say for certain. His body is bloated and crusted with a layer of wet, clinging salt, the result of the dreaded Brine Drinker mutation. Pale-skinned and red-haired, he moves with a strange, sluggish grace, his presence both unsettling and magnetic. In battle, Olg fights with a fury born not of ambition, but of bitter resentment—resentment for the twisted gift that ages him before his time and marks him as other among his kin.

At first glance, Brinehewer appears more like driftwood and scrap than a weapon—its haft swollen and warped by the sea, its blade mottled with rust, algae, and flaking barnacles. But in Olg Blóðsalt’s grip, the axe becomes a living extension of his cursed form. Forged long ago by a mad Skaeling blacksmith who quenched his blades in brine and blood, Brinehewer drinks deeply from every wound it inflicts. When it strikes, the corroded edge hisses, releasing bursts of caustic mist that eat away at armor and sear flesh with salt-laced agony. Legends say the axe does not merely kill—it preserves the bitterness of its victims, binding their fury into its pitted iron for the next swing. Few can stand before it twice.

The Saltmask is a corroded helm that clings to Olg Blóðsalt’s face like a second, blistered skin. Forged from bronze and iron dredged up from a sunken altar deep beneath the Kalti Delta, the mask was once a ceremonial tribute to a forgotten sea god. Now, it has fused to Olg’s features, its inner surface crusted with brine and jagged salt formations that draw blood with every breath he takes. The Saltmask reeks of damp decay and whispers with every wave, muffling Olg’s voice into a low, rasping gurgle. Yet in battle, it grants him terrifying clarity—his enemies seem sluggish and distant, like figures drowning in deep water. Some claim the mask sees for him, drawn to weakness and fear, guiding his axe toward those most ripe for ruin. Others say it hungers as he does, and that one day, it will drown him from within.
Marauder mobs are awarded even greater mobility when riding their crude chariots of bone and wood, lashed together with the guts and sinew of the vanquished.

Cast into the sea, the rusted relic wakes ancient things best left chained.
